deliberation: Checked the rhetorical questions for hyperbole or irony; they are straightforward. The only clear figurative expression is the idiomatic phrase 'the arm of YHWH', a standard metaphor/metonymy for God's effective power.

vehicle: strong human limb used for work and combat

effective agency and might
power / agency
posture: lament that this power is hidden from most
questioning / astonishment
prophetic lament and wonder
instances.explanation: The phrase ‘arm of YHWH’ does not refer to a literal limb but metaphorically (and metonymically) to God’s powerful, saving action manifested in history.

deliberation: Looked for similes introduced by כ- and for any hyperbole in the description of appearance. Found two explicit botanical similes describing the servant’s growth and vulnerability. The rest of the verse’s lack-of-beauty language is evaluative but not clearly figurative.

deliberation: Searched for similes and metaphorical epithets. Found (1) the title ‘a man of pains and acquainted with sickness’ as a metaphorical characterization and (2) an explicit simile comparing him to one from whom people hide their faces. The rest (despised, unesteemed) is literal social evaluation.

posture: emphasizing his stigma and marginalization
highlighting extremity of suffering as defining feature
prophetic portrayal of the servant as embodying affliction
instances.explanation: Calling him ‘a man of pains’ and ‘knowing sickness’ goes beyond stating he suffers; it metaphorically makes suffering and sickness his defining identity.

tone of regret and confession
community’s retrospective recognition of their misjudgment
instances.explanation: The servant is compared to someone from whom people avert their faces, symbolizing the community’s deep shame and rejection of him.

deliberation: Considered whether ‘sickness’ and ‘pains’ are strictly physical or stand for sins and their consequences. The verse closely parallels v.5 (sins/iniquities) and uses ‘bearing’ language, so I treated this as metaphorical, with illness imagery metonymically representing guilt borne by the servant.

instances.hebrew_text: אָכֵ֤ן חֳלָיֵ֙נוּ֙ ה֣וּא נָשָׂ֔א וּמַכְאֹבֵ֖ינוּ סְבָלָ֑ם

target: the servant’s substitutionary bearing of guilt and its consequences
vehicle: a person carrying heavy diseases or bodily afflictions

corrective explanation of a misjudged sufferer
theological insight into the servant’s role
instances.explanation: The ‘sicknesses’ and ‘pains’ he ‘carries’ are not merely his own ailments but metaphorically and metonymically represent the community’s sins and their consequences, depicted as transferable burdens of disease.

deliberation: Weighed whether the violent verbs are literal torture or figurative. Regardless of possible literal suffering, the climactic clause ‘by his bruises we were healed’ clearly uses medical-healing imagery for spiritual/moral restoration, making at least one unambiguous metaphor.

instances.english_text: He bore the chastisement that made us whole, and by his bruises we were healed

vehicle: disciplinary blows and bruises that produce healing

ground: his suffering becomes the means of our well-being

posture: grateful recognition of the paradoxical means of healing
theological interpretation of suffering as redemptive
affirmation of vicarious atonement through pain
instances.explanation: ‘Healing’ here extends beyond physical cure to comprehensive well-being and peace with God; the servant’s bruises and chastisement are metaphorically and metonymically portrayed as the means by which others are ‘healed’.

deliberation: Identified (1) an explicit simile comparing the people to straying sheep, (2) the usual metaphorical use of ‘way’ for a pattern of life, and (3) the metaphor of iniquity being laid upon the servant as if it were a transferable burden.

deliberation: Looked at the repeated ‘he did not open his mouth’ for hyperbole but it can be taken straightforwardly. The verse contains two parallel animal similes (lamb to slaughter, ewe before shearers) that clearly structure the verse’s imagery.

deliberation: Examined legal/judicial terms and especially the phrase ‘cut off from the land of the living’. That expression is a well-attested Biblical idiom: a metaphor comparing death (especially violent removal) to being severed from a country of the living.

instances.english_text: For he was cut off from the land of the living
target: the servant’s death and removal from human society
vehicle: being cut off from a land of the living
severing a person from a territory
exile or removal from a populated domain
ground: sudden, decisive termination of membership in the living community
violent or judicial exclusion from normal life
loss of place and status among the living
posture: sober portrayal of the extremity of injustice
highlighting the finality of the sentence
prophetic lament over the servant’s fate
instances.explanation: The phrase presents death as being ‘cut off’ from a ‘land of the living’, metaphorically depicting death as forcible removal from a realm of life.

deliberation: Considered whether ‘with the rich in his death’ or ‘with the wicked his grave’ are symbolic pairings (merism or metaphor). They can naturally be read as literal social categories describing where and with whom he was buried. No clear, necessary figurative device stood out; the verse is essentially narrative/judicial description.

Looked at possible anthropopathic language about God’s ‘pleasure’; this is traditional anthropomorphism but hard to isolate as a distinct figure per the given categories. The clearest figurative element is the cultic metaphor in which the servant’s ‘soul’ (life) is described as a ‘guilt offering’ (אָשָׁם).

instances.english_text: If he made himself an offering for guilt
target: the servant’s life given over to deal with sin
ground: his life functions like a sacrificial offering that atones for guilt
costly, consecrated giving up of life to restore relationship with God
substitutionary death with cultic efficacy
posture: cultic/theological interpretation of his death
elevating his suffering into priestly-sacrificial category
prophetic recasting of his death in temple imagery
instances.explanation: The servant’s ‘soul’ (metonymy for his life) is metaphorically identified with a guilt offering, drawing on sacrificial-cult imagery to interpret his self-giving as atonement.

deliberation: Assessed ‘seeing’ and ‘being satisfied’ as possibly metaphorical, but they can be taken straightforwardly as experiential results. The clearest figurative element is again the standard ‘bearing of iniquities’ motif, where sins are treated as burdens carried by the servant.

instances.english_text: It is their punishment [iniquities] that he bears

ground: sins conceptualized as weight or load that can be carried by another

doctrinal emphasis on substitutionary bearing
prophetic elucidation of the mechanism of justification
instances.explanation: The servant is said to ‘bear’ their iniquities, metaphorically and idiomatically treating guilt as a heavy burden borne on behalf of others.

deliberation: Noted several images: (1) sharing spoil with the strong as victory-exaltation imagery, (2) ‘poured out his soul to death’ as a vivid metaphor of total self-expending, and (3) again the ‘bearing of sin’ motif. All three are distinct and recurrent figures in the verse.

instances.explanation: The servant’s reward is pictured in military terms as sharing spoils, metaphorically representing honor, influence, and the ‘many’ themselves as his portion.
